settings.name: Spatial resolution for the UD raster
settings.description: Provide the grid size for the raster in which the Utilisation/Occurance Distribution will be estimated by the model (in metres). Default is 10000 m = 10 km, which might be too large for smaller-scale studies. Note that computation duration increases substantially with smaller grid sizes, and you may need to increase the 'Map extent' (see below).

settings.name: Estimated location error
settings.description: Provide the likely location error of your data (in metres). Defaults to 30 m.

settings.name: Contour percentages
settings.description: Provide the contour percentages to calculate and map, as a value between 0 and 1. These percentages represent the probability that a random animal of the tracked species is found in the estimated area(s) during the considered time period. Enter multiple contours in descending order and separated by commas (example: 0.999,0.9,0.75,0.5,0). To avoid empty central areas, include a zero at the end. Defaults to 0.999.

settings.name: Map extent increase
settings.description: Define the value for enlarging the map area beyond the outer boundaries of the locations. This value will be added evenly on all four directions. Often the value of half of the span of the data is sufficient (see the message in the logs of the App referring to the span of the used data after the first run). If you encounter an error that the area is too small, please increase this value. Unit = metre. Defaults to 20000 m = 20 km.

settings.name: Maximum time lag in hours
settings.description: Define the maximum time lag (in hours) to be included in the calculations, for example, two or three times the scheduled fix rate. This is to avoid unexpected results due to extended gaps in the data. Segments with gaps longer than this lag will not be included in the calculations. Decimals are allowed.

settings.name: Save as Shapefile
settings.description: Select if you want the results to include a shapefile containing the calculated contours.

references.note: Kranstauber, B., Kays, R., LaPoint, S. D., Wikelski, M., & Safi, K. (2012). A dynamic Brownian bridge movement model to estimate utilization distributions for heterogeneous animal movement. Journal of Animal Ecology, 81(4), 738-746.
